snippets.label: Presenting Complaint
snippets.content: Patient presents with symptoms of a urinary tract infection, including {dysuria|frequency|urgency|nocturia|haematuria|suprapubic pain}. Symptoms started [duration] ago. Symptom severity described as {mild|moderate|severe}.

snippets.label: Red Flag Assessment
snippets.content: Red flag screen: No signs of pyelonephritis (no loin pain, fever, rigors, nausea/vomiting). No signs of sepsis. Not pregnant and not breastfeeding. No known immunosuppression. No recurrent UTIs (2 in 6 months or 3 in 12 months). No vaginal discharge or symptoms suggestive of STI.

snippets.label: Key Diagnostic Symptoms
snippets.content: Patient reports [number] of the following key diagnostic symptoms: dysuria (burning pain when passing urine), new nocturia (needing to pass urine in the night), cloudy urine (visual inspection by pharmacist if practicable).

snippets.label: Alternative Diagnosis Exclusion
snippets.content: No vaginal discharge or irritation. No history suggestive of a sexually transmitted infection. No symptoms of genitourinary syndrome of menopause. No urethritis symptoms (post-coital irritation).

snippets.label: Treatment Plan (Supply)
snippets.content: Patient meets criteria for treatment under the Pharmacy First PGD. Supplied Nitrofurantoin 100mg MR capsules, one to be taken twice daily for 3 days. Advised to complete the course. Provided with TARGET UTI patient information leaflet. Pain management advice given (paracetamol/ibuprofen). Self-care advice provided (adequate hydration).

snippets.label: Self-Care Plan
snippets.content: Patient has mild symptoms. Advised on self-care measures: adequate hydration, pain relief (paracetamol/ibuprofen), and monitoring of symptoms. Provided with TARGET UTI patient information leaflet. Advised to return to pharmacy for reassessment if no improvement in 48 hours or if symptoms worsen.

snippets.label: Safety Netting
snippets.content: Advised to seek urgent medical attention (GP same-day or A&E) if: symptoms worsen rapidly, develop fever (≥37.9°C), loin pain, rigors, nausea/vomiting, or signs of sepsis. Advised to contact GP if symptoms do not improve within 48 hours of starting antibiotics, or if they develop signs of pyelonephritis.

illnessScript.summary: Uncomplicated lower UTI in women is a common presentation in community pharmacy. The Pharmacy First service enables pharmacists to assess, diagnose, and treat eligible patients using a structured pathway aligned to the nitrofurantoin PGD. The primary goals are to identify patients suitable for antibiotic treatment, exclude serious complications (pyelonephritis, sepsis), and ensure appropriate safety netting for those who do not meet PGD criteria or have mild symptoms suitable for self-care.

mustNotMiss.whyDangerous: Requires urgent same-day GP referral for systemic antibiotics to prevent sepsis and renal complications.
mustNotMiss.escalationConcern: Urgent same-day GP referral or A&E if systemically unwell.

redFlags: Signs of deterioration or serious illness
mustNotMiss.whyDangerous: Life-threatening condition requiring immediate hospital assessment and treatment.
Excluded from the Pharmacy First PGD. Requires GP management to prevent complications.
mustNotMiss.escalationConcern: Refer to GP for appropriate antibiotic choice and monitoring.

mustNotMiss.escalationConcern: Refer to sexual health clinic or GP.

mustNotMiss.whyDangerous: Excluded from the Pharmacy First PGD. Higher risk of complications and treatment failure.
mustNotMiss.escalationConcern: Refer to GP for assessment and appropriate antibiotic choice.

discriminators.question: How many of the 3 key diagnostic symptoms does the patient have?
discriminators.reasoning: The number of key diagnostic symptoms (dysuria, nocturia, cloudy urine) determines the likelihood of UTI and the appropriate treatment pathway.
discriminators.clinicalValue: Guides decision-making: 0 symptoms = UTI less likely (self-care), 1 symptom = UTI equally likely to other diagnosis (shared decision-making), 2-3 symptoms = proceed to antibiotic assessment.

discriminators.question: How severe are the patient's symptoms?
discriminators.reasoning: Symptom severity (mild vs. moderate to severe) guides the decision between self-care and antibiotic treatment.
discriminators.clinicalValue: Mild symptoms may be managed with self-care and pain relief as first-line treatment.

discriminators.question: Are there any systemic symptoms present?
discriminators.reasoning: The presence of systemic symptoms (fever, rigors, loin pain) differentiates lower UTI from pyelonephritis.
discriminators.clinicalValue: Systemic symptoms require urgent GP referral or A&E assessment.

whenHelpful.rationale: Indicated for recurrent UTI (2 in 6 months or 3 in 12 months) to guide antibiotic choice.

whenNotNeeded.rationale: Not routinely required for diagnosis in the Pharmacy First pathway if clinical features are present.

pharmacologicalConcepts.considerations: Nitrofurantoin 100mg MR twice daily for 3 days is the standard PGD treatment. Alternative: Nitrofurantoin 50mg immediate release four times daily for 3 days if MR unavailable.

delayedStrategies: For mild symptoms, consider self-care and pain relief as first-line treatment, with reassessment in 48 hours if no improvement.
followUpLogic: Advise to return to pharmacy or see GP if symptoms do not improve within 48 hours of starting antibiotics.
Advise to see GP if recurrent UTIs (2 in 6 months or 3 in 12 months) for further investigation.
